thread.title: Top 10: family-friendly Devon hotels

author: Telegraph Staff
title: Top 10: family-friendly Devon hotels
text:
Hotels Top 10: family-friendly Devon hotels An insider's guide to the best family-friendly Devon hotels, featuring the top places to stay for kids' clubs, swimming pools, surfing lessons, horse riding, games, magicians, babysitting and family entertainment, in locations including Salcombe, Woolacombe, Dartmoor and Torquay 7:00AM BST 26 Jul 2015 Comments Woolacombe Bay, Woolacombe 
The location is the best amongst Woolacombe’s hotels and there’s plenty to keep children busy in all weathers. Inside, there’s a swimming pool, table tennis and a play-den with games and mini beach huts. Outside, there’s a play area, nine-hole pitch-and-putt golf, a children’s pool and, of course, miles of sandy beach. Entertainers and supervised children’s film evenings are organised in the summer. Surfing lessons, horse riding and quad biking can be arranged. Qualified CRB-checked babysitters are available. 
Read the full review: Woolacombe Bay, Woolacombe 
For more information, see: woolacombe-bay-hotel.co.uk 
Read more: the best hotels in Devon Hotel Endsleigh, Tavistock 
A verdantly gardened, Grade I-listed Eden between Dartmoor and Exmoor. Dotted with grottos and dells, Endsleigh’s gardens and grounds are perfect for games of hide-and-seek and make a scenic spot for a family picnic, which the hotel can set up along with blankets and lanterns. In the summer, Chelsea Flower Show gold medal florist, Amanda Randell, runs gardening activities, and there’s a potting shed where the green-fingered can start growing their own plants to take home at the end of their stay. Baby monitors, meals, bottle warmers and babysitting are available. 
Read the full review: Hotel Endsleigh, Tavistock 
For more information, see: hotelendsleigh.com Soar Mill Cove, Salcombe 
With a rugged Devon cove and beach all to itself, this is very nearly the perfect package. There’s snooker, ping pong, board games and a rocking horse, as well as tennis rackets, golf clubs, boogie boards, crab lines, buckets and spades for outings to Soar Mill Cove, just a few minutes walk from the hotel. Magicians, lawn games, cupcake decorating and cinema nights are laid on in the summer. Farley and Daisy, the hotel’s golden Labradors, are popular with young guests. 
Read more: the best hotels in Devon Cary Arms, Babbacombe 
Set beneath the cliffs on the beach at Babbacombe, the Cary Arms’ location is nothing short of spectacular. On arrival, children are given a bucket, spade and fishing net with which to go rock pooling on Babbacombe Bay, a quiet beach by the hotel that has calm water and a friendly local seal. The hotel’s four self-catering cottages are well set up for families, with board games and children’s books, as is the Captain’s Suite in the main hotel. Local family activities include Paignton Zoo and Splashdown Waterpark. 
Read the full review: Cary Arms, Babbacombe 
For more information, see: caryarms.co.uk Saunton Sands, Braunton 
More village than hotel, this 120-room beachside behemoth is crammed with facilities. Designed for parents who want to travel light, there’s free use of a huge range of baby and child equipment and cheap hire of bulky items such as buggies, baby baths, potties and baby carriers. Two free hours of childcare is included in a stay, as well as free surfing lessons. The hotel has a heated indoor and outdoor pool, and there are miles of sandy beach on the doorstep. In school holidays, family film nights, archery, falconry displays and magic shows are organised. 
Read the full review: Saunton Sands, Braunton 
For more information, see: sauntonsands.co.uk Bovey Castle, Dartmoor 
Rain-lashed ramblers, outdoorsy families, golfers and the huntin’ shootin’ fishin’ brigade will stay here. There’s tennis, croquet and a playground in the extensive grounds, with a huge programme of outdoor children’s activities organised as part of Bovey Rangers club. These include survival skills, archery, reptile and owl encounters, rock climbing, raft building, canoeing and golf lessons. The indoor playroom, costing £20 per session, has painting, pottery, biscuit decorating, mask, puppet and badge making. Babysitting services can be arranged in advance, as well as hire of baby equipment. 
Read the full review: Bovey Castle, Dartmoor 
For more information, see: boveycastle.com South Sands, Salcombe 
If you love walking or watersports then look no further than this hotel. White sands and calm seas are a beach ball’s throw from the hotel, and complimentary buckets, spades and beach bags are given to families on arrival so they can make the most of it. During the school holidays, the hotel stages family events, including a summer solstice beach party. Most rooms in the hotel are for couples only, but additional beds can be arranged for some rooms and there are five beach suites designed for families of up to six. 
Read the full review: South Sands, Salcombe 
For more information, see: southsands.com 
Read more: the best hotels in Devon The Thurlestone, Salcombe 
The setting is classic Devon: to the front of the hotel is rugged coastline backed by sheep-filled pastures. There’s an indoor playroom with plenty of games, an outdoor playground, mini golf, family badminton courts, a nature trail, bird feeders and a ‘Close Encounters’ shed where young visitors can learn how to handle stick insects, praying mantis, scorpions, tarantula and snakes. In the school holidays, there’s a children’s arts and crafts club, teddy bears’ picnics in the grounds, and entertainers. 
Read the full review: The Thurlestone, Salcombe 
For more information, see: thurlestone.co.uk Highbullen Hotel, Chittlehamholt 
Highbullen is a luxury, gothic-fronted country house hotel spread over a 125-acre Devon estate. With such a broad range of facilities on offer, Highbullen prides itself on being a ‘multi-generational’ hotel, catering for extended families with children aged eight and over. Dedicated rooms for families of four have sofa beds and pullout beds, while large families can hire out lodges exclusively. Children will particularly enjoy the giant outdoor chessboard and games simulator. 
Read the full review: Highbullen Hotel, Chittlehamholt 
For more information, see: highbullen.co.uk The Imperial, Torquay 
The Imperial is a family and dog-friendly seaside hotel with a rich Victorian heritage overlooking the English Riviera. A games room has table tennis, a pool table and computer game consoles; there’s an indoor creative play area for toddlers; an outdoor play area with AstroTurf; crazy golf and a selection of mini-rides. There’s plenty of choice of rooms for families, with 13 family suites and six standard family rooms. In the summer holidays, the hotel lays on magicians and face painters, along with an extensive programme of activities including family quizzes, scuba-diving, pyjama parties and teddy bears’ picnics. 
Read the full review: The Imperial, Torquay 
For more information, see: thehotelcollection.co.uk/hotels/torquay-imperial-hotel
